title: 107_s249
content: The "Renewable Energy Development Incentives Act" may be cited as the short title. The Act includes the expansion of renewable resource credit to include alternative resources. The "Renewable Energy Development Incentives Act" expands the renewable resource credit to include alternative resources such as solar, biomass, incremental hydropower, and geothermal energy. The term 'biomass' refers to nonhazardous waste materials derived from forest resources, agriculture sources, and waste pallets, crates, and tree trimmings. The term 'incremental hydropower' refers to additional generating capacity achieved through increased efficiency or new capacity at a non-Federal hydroelectric project. This definition is added to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to define a 'qualified facility'. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a definition of 'qualified facility' for facilities using alternative resources to produce electricity. This definition applies to facilities owned by the taxpayer placed in service after December 31, 1992. Additionally, government-owned facilities using poultry waste or alternative resources are eligible for tax credits. Qualified facilities with co-production are subject to limitations and adjustments under Section 45(b) of the Code. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include an increased credit for co-production facilities. This applies to qualified facilities described in subsection (c)(3)(D) or (A), (B), or (C) of subsection (c)(3) that add a co-production facility after the enactment date. The credit amount for an eligible taxable year is increased by .25 cents. A co-production facility is defined as a facility that... Qualified facilities located within qualified Indian lands can benefit from an increased credit for co-production facilities, which produce heat, mechanical power, or minerals in addition to electricity on a continuous basis. An eligible taxable year is defined as one where gross receipts from the co-production facility are at least 10 percent of the gross receipts from electricity production. Section 45(b) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to provide an increased credit for qualified facilities located within qualified Indian lands or lands held in trust by a Native Corporation, operated with approval of the Indian tribal government or Native Corporation. The amendment increases the credit for qualified facilities on Indian lands or lands held in trust by a Native Corporation with approval of the tribal government. The effective date for these amendments applies to taxable years beginning after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 2. ADDITIONAL MODIFICATIONS OF RENEWABLE RESOURCE CREDIT. Section 45(d) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allow for the transferability of the credit for qualified facilities through agreements with organizations purchasing or selling electricity, or for owners exempt from tax. Coordination with other credits is also addressed in this section. Expansion to include animal waste in the renewable energy production tax credit, allowing for electricity generated from poultry waste or other animal waste. Qualified facilities not complying with pollution laws are also addressed in the tax code. The tax code is amended to address noncompliance with pollution laws for qualified facilities. Special rules for the renewable electricity production credit are also introduced. The tax code is amended to address noncompliance with pollution laws for qualified facilities and introduces special rules for the renewable electricity production credit. The credit is applied separately from section 39, with limitations and reductions based on other credits allowed for the taxable year. The tax code is amended to address noncompliance with pollution laws for qualified facilities and introduces special rules for the renewable electricity production credit, making it permanent and expanding qualified facility dates. The tax code amendments remove a specific date restriction for qualified facilities and apply to energy produced after the enactment of the Act.
